text: ah hey y'all
Anthony Fantino here Internet's scratchy
throat music nerd and it's time for a
review Lupe Fiasco food and liquor to
the great American rap album part 1 Lupe
Fiasco is a Chicago rapper who made a
pretty nice entry into the hip hop
industry with a debut album that was
lauda Daz just one of the best hip hop
albums of 2006 this album was filled
with catchy emotive production from the
likes of Kanye West's soundtrack The
Neptunes even Linkin Park's Mike Shinoda
produced a track for this thing and of
course movie brought maybe what he is
best known for his very sharp
thought-provoking lyricism with a very
socially conscious edge it was just
awesome to see somebody so high up in
the hip hop industry with hit singles
like kick push and daydreaming but also
had kind of a refreshing perspective you
know wasn't rapping about the same stuff
that everybody else was now the very
next year Lupe put out another LP the
cool this album featured way more
production from soundtrack Lupe
lyrically was getting a bit more bold a
bit more maybe preachy in a sense and he
took a more conceptual route with the
overall theme of the album and I feel
like his more topical tracks on this LP
were way more pointed like the song hip
hop saved my life this LP is not as
celebrated as food and liquor and of
course there are reasons I mean it's not
as immaculately produced you know
definitely some questionable decisions I
guess on this album but nobody saw what
was coming down the pipe with what Lupe
did last year with what was his latest
album lasers the LP had a lot of
pre-release drama the album's coming out
a way it's not coming out
then he claimed that his label made him
make decisions that he wouldn't have
made otherwise in regards to the hooks
or the instrumentals no matter what the
drama where the real story was what the
end result was on on lasers was
basically a socially conscious hip-hop
album yes but with some very glitzy
electronic and kind of sterile
instrumentals that made Eminem's
recovery look like it went as hard as
Death Grips lyrically Lupe was still on
point sure you know you couldn't really
knock a lot of his messages on these
tracks and and there were some decent
singles on here like the pretty
inspirational the show goes on but these
pop beats are just too sweet on the ears
not really representative of the urgency
of some of the situations that Lupe was
rapping about especially when you're
getting these very bright loud auto-tune
courses on the track beautiful lasers I
mean that just really kind of made songs
on here despite what Lupe was saying cut
of unlistenable I kind of feel the same
way about the track state-run radio I
mean you know I could really agree with
what a lot of Lupe is saying on here but
you know I'm not into music for just the
philosophy of it you know I mean I could
totally agree with you and and that's
cool you could be making a point that I
am 100% behind but if it doesn't sound
good I mean you know that I'm not liking
it you know nothing against your
ideology but I'm not liking your music
and I feel like ever since the release
of lasers Lupe has kind of been in the
midst of damage control he put out the
friend of the people mixtape shortly
after the release of lasers and that
mixtape ironically featured him rapping
over more electronic beats which I
previously thought were being forced
upon him on lasers but now about a year
later we have a new full-length album
whose title evokes Lupe Fiasco's most
celebrated album food and liquor
specifically food and liquor two
the great American rap album part one
the part one is really there and I'm
sure eventually we're going to get to
Lupe Fiasco food and liquor too
the great American rap album part two
electric Boogaloo you know usually I
could just totally give a she she she
she she in terms of what the album title
is with an LP but there's just so much
pretense that comes with this title not
only does the title imply that this LP
is going to continue upon what made food
and liquor great but the great American
rap album part one well I feel like I
can confidently say that this is not
really a continuation of food and liquor
and if it is it's it's really one of
those movie sequels where 90% maybe 95%
of everyone involved is like completely
gone the lead role Lupe is still there
but we've got different directors the
love interest we remember from the last
movie is like a completely different
woman she was like a blonde in the first
movie and now she's like a redhead and
they're just kind of crossing the
fingers and hoping that no notices and
the fact that we do have a beat from
soundtrack on on the second song here is
really the only thing production wise
that makes this album resemble food and
liquor the biggest issue with this album
and it continues to be an issue with
Lupe is the production a lot of the
instrumentals on this thing sound like
they would have been popping behind
gangsta rap club hits in the mid or
early 2000s the beats on this thing with
the exception of a few are just really
forgettable bland and in kind of generic
thin and just not a lot of punch not a
lot of energy to them though they are
not as bright or flashy or electronic as
lasers I do think they're as poppy
despite the fact that what a lot of Lupe
is saying is real I feel like musically
and instrumentally he sugarcoats it all
the way I do like the soundtrack
instrumental on strange fruition even
though a lot of people kind of had some
drama over the Pete Rock inspired sample
on the track around my way and I don't
really think
that sample was executed in the most
tasteful way possible I mean the beat is
a little bland I do like the fact they
are kind of tributing you know that era
of hip-hop with that song and the
instrumental behind the track cold war
is pretty great too i like the the
breathy vocal sample on there and jane
totally just murders that hook was very
powerful and passionate vocals but
outside of that tracks like [ __ ] bad I
mean the instrumental on the thing just
sounds so kind of cheap thrown together
not really all that detail same thing
with a track like Lamborghini angels I
don't like that instrumental at all
either and if there's one thing that
disappoints as much as the instrumentals
on this thing is the hooks like on the
track it tau which kind of comes out
right at the gate with this LP where
Lupe Fiasco really says and some kisses
for the babies like is he for serious I
know the song has positive vibes it's
well intended
it's wishing the world were a better
place it's optimistic its idealistic but
could Lupe have maybe tried either
instrumentally or or lyrically to make
that idea sound maybe a little less
corny than it actually is and when he's
singing that hook later on the track
with the auto-tune it just sounds
terrible the track heart donor has a
terrible hook as well and the song is
unforgettable youth and battle scarves
actually kind of sound like hooks that
would make it onto an Eminem LP one of
his new ones you know it's it's
definitely not as shockingly bad as
lasers but maybe that's only because the
shock is kind of worn off at this point
I mean if there's anything I can applaud
on this album it's the lyrics I did like
a lot of Lupe's lyrics on lasers but
what kind of makes this help pay better
than lasers is that you can actually
hear them a lot of the time whereas the
production on that last LP was was
overshadowing hibbett points I do really
like Lupe's verses on the track
Lamborghini angels where he is throwing
some really sharp and pointed criticisms
at religion and I like the way how Lupe
has three verses that tell kind of three
sides to the story in the track pitch
bed and then you just kind of ties them
together at the end there are times when
I do kind of feel like Lupe takes his
point and he kind of just beats the
listener over the head with it as
opposed to being abstract maybe kind of
letting people come to their own
conclusions I'm not really sure how much
further I can I can kind of go on with
this album I mean I'm just going to keep
running around in circles at this point
if I talk anymore yeah I can keep
praising and keep talking about lines
that Lupe spits out in song concepts
that he pulls together on this album the
track hood now is great so is cold war
so it was around my way lyrically but
I'm just not liking the instrumentals on
a majority of this album they really
just kind of take the energy and the
power out of a lot of what Lupe is
saying I mean there is more urgency and
and passion in the slam poetry on the
track Ayesha says that kicks this album
off then a lot of these songs with Lupe
rapping over these weak instrumentals so
again I don't really disagree with a lot
of Lupe's points and I like that he's
you know spreading this message and
giving it to his listeners and a lot of
them take it seriously but I mean me
instrumentally and maybe even
philosophically too I'm just going to
kind of hang with the league of great
socially conscious rappers to come
before Lupe most def telling quali black
star Boogie Down Productions A Tribe
Called Quest Public Enemy the roots
common and despite the fact that a lot
of those artists are older you know
let's be honest a lot of the problems
that they rapped about are still kind of
problems so to be completely honest I'm
really feeling a strong four to a light
five on this album definitely
improvement over lasers but Lube eight
really needs to get back to picking some
good production did you love this LP did
you hate it why and what should I review
next anthony Fantana Lupe Fiasco
food and liquor - forever
